Situation1: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: A family has requested a final, mandatory preparation session for their child's imminent and significant religious sacrament.
Story: It was a slow afternoon at the grocery store, and I stood behind the register, scanning items for the handful of customers trickling in. My mind was half on the beeping scanner, half on the text I’d just received: a family from my parish needed me to lead a last-minute preparation session for their child’s sacrament—tonight, no exceptions. As a cashier, I was expected to stay until my shift ended, making sure every transaction was perfect, every drawer balanced. But as a priest, I was the only one who could guide this family through the final steps of their child’s spiritual journey. I could see the mother’s anxious face in my mind, hear the urgency in her voice. Yet, here I was, tied to the register, with my manager expecting me to finish my shift without complaint. My hands moved automatically, but my heart was torn, caught between the demands of my job and my calling, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
